proposals.reasoning: Alice has broad early trust as a stable anchor, and pairing her with me avoids auto-locking Bob as trusted while still keeping the first mission relatively low-drama. This combo fits what several people suggested (Alice-centered but not with Bob), and it gives the table a clean, simple data point to start building reads on both a generally trusted player and someone who isn’t already being auto-cleared.

votes.comment: Fits consensus of Alice-centered, non-Bob first team for low-drama info; no strong reason yet to distrust Diana over others.
My preferences were Alice-centered and low-drama; this fits that and gives us an early data point on Diana without auto-clearing Bob.
I’d rather not risk including the leader on Mission 1; I prefer an Alice + Charlie/Bob start for a cleaner baseline.
I’m on it, and a mixed team on Mission 1 gives evil flexibility while looking perfectly reasonable to the table.
Mission 1 is low-info anyway; Alice is a reasonable anchor, and pairing her with Diana avoids auto-clearing Bob too early while giving us a clean data point on both of them.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low-risk—something like me plus one other, ideally someone who’s usually steady under scrutiny, maybe Bob or Diana. Early on we mostly want a clean result to build some trust, so I’d avoid putting anyone who’s already sounding too eager or chaotic on the first team.

I’m fine with you taking the lead here, Alice—early info is more important than galaxy-braining it. I’d slightly prefer a “low-drama” pair like you and Charlie or you and me, just so we get a cleaner read from the first mission.

I like the idea of keeping Mission 1 low-drama too—Alice plus me seems like a straightforward way to get an early read without overcomplicating things. If people are uneasy about that, I’d still lean Alice-centered but avoid stacking it with someone we’re already debating a lot.

I’m good with keeping Alice as the anchor, but I’d slightly prefer pairing her with me or Charlie so we can start building a read on someone who isn’t already getting universal “auto-trust” treatment like Bob.
I’m fine with Alice on Mission 1, but I’d rather pair her with Charlie or Diana than Bob so we don’t just auto-trust Bob this early and can spread our info a bit.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean Alice–Diana result is encouraging but doesn’t clear either of them, since a 2‑person success can easily include an evil who chose not to fail early. I want to anchor on Alice from the successful team while not automatically locking Diana in as trusted. Adding Bob and Charlie gives us maximum new information this round: we keep one proven-success member (Alice) and test two entirely new players, which helps us map alignment faster than just re‑running Alice–Diana plus one unknown. If this team succeeds, we gain strong confidence in Alice/Bob/Charlie and also increase suspicion on Diana by comparison; if it fails, we’ve tightly constrained where evil must sit among these three without having overcommitted to the Mission 1 pair.

votes.comment: I’m on the team and it gives strong info by testing two new players without auto-clearing Diana from a 2‑person success.
This matches the info-gathering approach I argued for earlier: keep Alice from the clean mission and add two new players instead of auto-locking in Diana.
Too many untested players at once and we’re sidelining Diana after a clean first mission; I’d rather keep at least one of the original pair and only add one new unknown.
I’m fine sitting out while we get info on two new players with Alice; with Bob on the team we still have sabotage potential if needed.
This matches the team structure I suggested (Alice plus two new players), maximizes information gain, and there’s no concrete reason yet to distrust any of them.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to keep both Diana and me on the team and add one new person—maybe start with Bob or Charlie—so we’re building off confirmed success while only introducing one unknown.

Building off the clean first mission makes sense, so I’m happy with you and Diana staying on, and I’d lean toward adding either me or Charlie rather than Eve for now since we’ve seen less from her so far.

I like building off Alice from the clean first mission, but I’d rather not treat Diana as fully confirmed from just a 2‑person success—maybe try Alice plus two of Bob/Charlie/Eve so we start testing more people early.
I’m inclined to stick with the proven pair from Mission 1 and just add one new person, and between the options I slightly prefer bringing in Bob this round so we’re not overhauling the team too fast.

I’m okay using the Alice–Diana success as a starting point, but a 2‑person clean doesn’t clear anyone, so I’d slightly prefer Alice plus two new people (something like Alice–Bob–Charlie) over just re‑running Diana and hoping the third is the only unknown.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with exactly this pair was clean, and Mission 2’s single fail guarantees at least one evil among {Bob, Charlie, Alice}. Since I know I’m good, that means the fail must have come from Bob or Charlie. The safest 2-player team is therefore to exclude both Bob and Charlie and reuse the only fully successful pairing we’ve seen: Alice + Diana. Including Eve here would just add an extra unknown without any need, while we already have a proven clean result from this exact duo.

votes.comment: From my POV at least one of Bob/Charlie is evil from the Mission 2 fail, and Alice+Diana is the only already-tested clean pair that excludes both, so this is the safest 2-player team.
I still don’t love reusing the same pair, but with heat on Mission 2’s team this is at least a low-risk way to avoid Bob/Charlie while we gather more info.
I don’t like reusing a pair as if it’s confirmed; an early clean result doesn’t clear either player, so I’d rather see a mix that isn’t just repeating Mission 1.
As evil on the team, I want this mission so I can control whether it passes or fails later while keeping suspicion on Bob/Charlie.

From my perspective, the only players not on the failed mission are Diana and me, so the safest 2-person team is Diana + Eve. Reusing Alice + Diana still risks Alice being the Mission 2 traitor, and it unnecessarily excludes a known-untainted player: me.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean with just me and Diana, I’d really like to see us go back to that pairing here—there’s exactly one evil in Bob/Charlie from Mission 2, so keeping both of them off this small team feels safest.

I get why Alice wants to repeat Mission 1, but a clean first mission with Diana doesn’t clear either of them—evil loves passing early to look safe—so I’d rather see a mix like Diana/Charlie or Alice/Charlie than just rerunning the exact same pair.

Given Mission 2’s fail, I’m more inclined to keep Bob off the next team and lean on players who’ve only been on clean missions or sat out, so something like Alice + Charlie (or even Charlie + Eve) feels like a reasonable, low-variance choice here.

I’m leaning to just repeat Alice + me here: with the fail coming from within {Alice, Bob, Charlie}, keeping both Bob and Charlie off a 2-person team feels like the lowest-risk way to avoid another hit while we get more info.

From my point of view, the only completely untainted people are those who weren’t on the failed mission, so I’d most like to see a team of Diana + me here. If you really don’t want me on it, I’d fall back to repeating Alice + Diana over involving Bob or Charlie again on a 2-person team.

proposals.reasoning: Given that Alice is the only player on both failed missions and Diana was on the most recent fail, the cleanest consistency play is to leave both of them off this team. A lineup of me, Charlie, and Eve matches what multiple people have already said they’re most comfortable with, avoids the main sources of suspicion, and gives us a fresh combination that doesn’t include the common denominator from the prior failures.

votes.comment: Given I know I’m good, Mission 3’s fail makes Diana highly likely evil, and Mission 2’s fail then most plausibly points to Bob as the second evil. The proposed team includes Bob, whom I strongly suspect, and excludes me and Charlie+Eve is the safer good pairing with me. I don’t trust this lineup.
This keeps both Alice, who was on both failed missions, and Diana, who was on the latest fail, off the team and gives us a fresh combo without the main sources of suspicion.

Still not comfortable putting Bob back on a mission after the M2 fail; feels like we’re over-indexing on Alice as the common denominator and not considering that the fail could easily have come from him.
This keeps both repeated suspects (Alice, me) off the mission and follows the table’s stated consistency logic, so it looks like the safest, most agreed-upon option.
Consistent logic to exclude Alice (on both fails) and Diana (on latest fail); BCE is the cleanest, most agreed-on option and matches my stated preference.

discussion.content: Given the double-dip on teams with me and Diana where only the second one failed, I really don’t want Diana on this next mission; I’d like to see a team of me, Eve, and either Bob or Charlie, with us talking through which of those two feels safer.

If we’re being consistent, Alice is the only player on both failed missions, so I actually feel better about a team that *excludes* her this time. I’d lean toward something like Eve, me, and Charlie, since that avoids the common denominator while still giving us a fresh mix.

Given how the fails line up, I’d really prefer we avoid putting both a repeat from Mission 2 and Mission 3 together again, so keeping Bob and Diana off this one feels safest. A team of Alice, Eve, and me seems like a reasonable compromise that gives us a fresh look without the main sources of suspicion.

From a consistency standpoint, Alice being on both failed missions really can’t be ignored, so I’m actually okay staying off and would rather see something like Eve, Bob, and Charlie go. That keeps the common denominator out while still giving us a mostly fresh read.
Given Alice is the only one on both failed missions and Diana was on the latest fail, I really don’t want either of them on this team. I’m most comfortable with a lineup of me, Bob, and Charlie here.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was consistently willing to go on early teams and didn’t shy away from taking leadership on Mission 3, but I clearly misread the table, especially trusting Diana too long and not pushing harder on alternative team comps. Next time I should be more vocal about scrutinizing repeat pairs on teams and use voting patterns more systematically instead of leaning on gut reads.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled evil game, blending into the middle of discussions and using Mission 2’s single fail to avoid drawing attention while still pushing teams that kept him included later.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he tried to steer subtly rather than overtly, but his caution made it harder for good to lock in a strong read on evil before it was too late.
player_observations.Diana: Very assertive and confident, which made her look reliably good early, and she leveraged that trust well, especially on Missions 1 and 3, to keep suspicion away from herself as assassin.
player_observations.Eve: Played an open, cooperative good style, but her involvement in the failed Mission 2 made her look suspicious, and she struggled to fully shake that shadow afterward despite mostly reasonable suggestions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fail cards well and blended into team selections convincingly enough to secure the win without drawing overwhelming suspicion. I could improve by more actively shaping table narratives instead of mostly reacting, especially around framing specific players as ‘safe’ or ‘risky’ to better control later team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and was generally trusted, but the failed team she led on Mission 3 suggests she didn’t sufficiently scrutinize partner selection or push hard enough to re-evaluate assumptions after earlier fails.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, Charlie stayed cautious and didn’t over-clear anyone too loudly, which helped him survive, but his influence on team building wasn’t strong enough to consistently keep evil off missions.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, Diana balanced early cooperation (Mission 1 success) with later subtlety, avoiding looking blatantly evil; however, her early clean mission may have made it slightly harder to later frame strong suspicions on key good players.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a careful, logical good player, but her Mission 2 team choice (including me) showed she relied a bit too much on surface-level trust rather than aggressively challenging team compositions after a fail.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified that Bob and Diana were likely evil relatively early, but I failed to communicate that clearly enough through my voting and team suggestions without outing myself as Merlin. I also didn’t do a good job protecting Alice and Eve from suspicion after Mission 2 failed, which let evil steer the narrative and missions in their favor.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission partners and stayed consistent in her reads, which made her look genuine but also made it easier for evil to anchor suspicion on her after the later fails. She didn’t push very aggressively for alternative team compositions, which kept her from fully clearing herself in the group’s eyes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, measured evil game—he joined key missions, dropped just enough doubt on others, and avoided looking like the loud driver of any bad decision. His willingness to go on risky teams without over-defending himself helped him blend in as a cautious but cooperative good player.
player_observations.Diana: Assassin play was subtle and opportunistic; she stayed just active enough in discussion to seem engaged but not so strong in her reads that she drew heat. She leveraged the mission outcomes well to back up plausible narratives and ended with a reasonably accurate guess for Merlin, which sealed the win.
player_observations.Eve: Showed a generally good, logical approach to team selection and mission analysis, but was a bit too trusting of the wrong people after Mission 2. Her arguments were sound, yet she didn’t push them forcefully enough to overturn the growing suspicion narrative that evil was constructing.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with my fellow evil teammate by keeping an early clean mission and then choosing a small, controlled team for a decisive fail later, which helped maintain my cover long enough for evil to secure the win. I could improve by creating a bit more visible doubt around Charlie earlier, as Merlin, so that if it had come down to an assassination decision, I’d have had a more robust social case prepared.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust and include herself in teams consistently, which made her look confident but also left her somewhat vulnerable to being framed when a small team failed. Her willingness to go on both a clean and then a failed mission showed she’s comfortable taking center stage in team selection.
player_observations.Bob: Played a classic subtle-evil game by only showing up on one failed mission and otherwise blending into the background of voting and discussion. His team choice on Mission 4 was aggressive but effective, indicating he’s willing to take a calculated risk once suspicion is already scattered.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he guided mission outcomes effectively while staying just cautious enough not to be overtly accusatory, which helped keep him alive to the endgame. His reads were strong but delivered in a low-key manner that made it harder for evil to confidently lock onto him.
player_observations.Eve: Showed a generally cautious and logical approach to team selection but ended up on a failing mission that slightly undermined her credibility. She seemed to rely more on mission results than social reads, which made her play solid but somewhat predictable from an evil perspective.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of early mission results, especially Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to reconsider assumptions after Mission 2 failed with only one evil among Alice/Bob/Charlie. I should have been more skeptical of Bob after Mission 2 and much more resistant to the Mission 4 team, given that it repeated the same suspicious core (Bob + Charlie) that had already produced a fail.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared cooperative and safe, especially through Mission 1’s success and volunteering for small teams, which made her feel like a default ‘trusted’ pick and reduced scrutiny on her. Her willingness to be on both a success and a fail team without over-defending herself made her look like someone comfortable letting the table draw its own conclusions.
player_observations.Bob: Positioned himself in the center of key mission teams and leveraged the ambiguity of single-fail missions very effectively. He played just cautious enough that the focus of suspicion didn’t firmly lock onto him until too late, and he benefited from being repeatedly grouped with Charlie to muddy reads.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he balanced subtle steering with not drawing too much attention, but his apparent trust in some evil-inclusive teams (like Mission 4) made it hard for me to separate his information advantage from normal good uncertainty. His calm presence and non-panicked behavior after fails made him look like a stable, trustworthy anchor, which helped evil hide in his shadow.
player_observations.Diana: Set a strong tone early by leading a clean Mission 1, which built a lot of long-term trust for her and made her look like a reliable early-game reference point. As assassin, she stayed relatively low-key after that, letting others argue around more contentious missions while keeping her image as a safe, reasonable player intact.
